Overall : Wow this is good. Nice nutty and spicy profile with a strong yeast presence. Quite sugary but not overly sweet. Very nice beer. I like the sugary profile with the nutty notes. Well balanced, quite drinkable. No traces of the 10% alcohol, pretty impressive. Awesome stuff !

Aroma:nutty and dark fruit.....
Appearance:Dark brown,good tan head...
Flavor:nutty,dark fruit,light oxydation flavor...

Deep brown with red glow, large floaties, thick brown head.
Aroma is liquorice, yeast, wine, fruit, a bit buttery.
Flavour is thinner then expected, slight earthy liquorice and hop bitterness evolving into sweet fruit.
Lemon drop nose.  Amber-brown with strong head.  Lemony, syrupy (in a good way) with a light nuttiness and dry...a bit barleywinish.

Aroma of sour cherries, cloves, dark chocolate and toffee. Appearance is murky brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, with sweet toffee and even nougat as well. Palate is bubbly and lively. Oh man...

Appearance: Pours coppey red color with full of sediments and intense, effervescent look. Thick, light-beige head with viscous lacing and good retention.

Aroma: Dozens of mellow dark fruits like rum-soaked prunes and figs, dried-banana, strawberry candies and with a honeyish toasted malts with soft cadi-sugar sweetness.

Flavor: Mellow, fermented dried fruits fills the whole palate with evident but gentle and soft candi sweetnes. Mild coriander and cinammon spiciness balance the sweetness at the medium and leads to a cognac or rum-soaked dried fruity character.

Mouthfeel/Palate: Effervescent, syrupy textured brew with complex fruity palate. Absolutely hidden alcohol warmth.

Overall: Amazing BSA with amazingly complex fruity character. What a holly pack of dried fruits!!!

Deep brown pour, off white head. Huge aroma of sweet yeasty bread. Dark Candi sugar and loads of sweet malts. Its like drinking. A beer cake. So many dark fruit flavors. Picture dark sweet savoury fruit beer cake. Awesome!

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Poured a opaque, murky brown with a dark orange tint... thin tan head (gone fast) - a lot of sediment in my glass. Amazing aroma: very floral, fresh fruits. Taste: caramel & roasted malts, maybe a note of chocolate, alcohol (alcohol gets stronger as it warms). Mild carbonation. Finish was good but short lived: sweet with alcohol warming. Sticky mouth feel. Overall: good but a little too sugary for me. Medium body, had some depth and complexity, decent balance. This beer is more like a Quadrupel than a Triple to me. Also, near the end of my glass (after the beer had fully warmed) large yeast particles started floating atop the beer... Ive never seen this happen before.
11.2 oz bottle. Dark brown pour with a thick tan head. Chocolate, toffee, brown sugar and Belgian yeast esters in the aroma. Malty thick, brown sugar, toffee, cherry and Belgian esters. Very good.

750ml bottle, best by 2010, bottled 2008.  Served cool room temp into a Duvel tulip.  This baby wants to be a gusher, 3-minutes carefully working the cap to relieve pressure.  Also completely unfiltered, just like its siblings Brune and Grand Cru, the beer is loaded with large floaty chunks of yeast and sediment, more than any other beer Ive seen.  Pours a rich copper brown with a light beige head that holds a wispy cap and ring, but doesnt leave much lacing at all.  Aroma is a strong and powerful dose of rich dark fruits, candy sugar, spice, yeast and bread.  The aroma comes together very nicely and is a treat to inhale.  Flavor is rich and malty, dark fruits, but also some banana, candy sugar, bread, yeast.  Sweet overall.  Mouthfeel gets a bit sticky, yet finishes a bit watery, medium bodied, soft carbonation.  Very nice for a dark triple, although not quite to the level of Gulden Draak.

Courtesy of my favorite nutsack, Cavie. The aroma is really nutty, possibly nuttier than any Ive smelled... the sweetness combined in there makes it smell very much like peanut butter.  The flavor is sweet, nutty, slightly boozey, raisins, malty, and more. Carbonation burns a bit more than Id like for bottle conditioning.

Szép mély rubinvörös színe van,amit egy piszkos fehér hatalmas és krémes hab fed be,ami nagyon lassan olvad el és nem nyom nélkül.Illata alkoholosan édeskés,mazsolás és kicsit kakaó poros.Íze fanyar és édeskés egyben mint egy málnaboré vagy más piros gyümölcsből készült erjesztett italé.Érezni benne egy kis tejsavas mellék ízt és a komló kesernyéssége is kidugja fejét a háttérből és megint itt a kakaó és egy kevés fahéj.Elég testes és közepesen szénsavas ital.Keserédes utóíze van ami szárazon és egy kicsit porosan ér véget.Érdekes és összetett egy sör.

Poured very dark and opaque brown. Tan-coloured, substantial head with a good amount of lacing. Malty flavour but smooth and drinkable. Quite a bit of yeast floating in it. Abrupt finish. Almost a chocolatey flavour. A little much for me overall but worth a try.
nice dark brown color on pour. smells very nutty, like peanut butter lol.  a bit sweet and tangy up front. a bit bitter on the aftertaste.  a little too carbonated but not terribly.  good beer!

Bottle. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Brown colour. Way too cloudy and with huge yeast åparticles. Mpderate malty and hoppy nice aroma with yeasty notes. Moderate bitter excellent fruity flavor. Strong plumb and chocolate notes. Lonfg nice moderate bitter finish. Creamy palate.

750 ml bottle. A cloudy dark amber to brown beer with a quite small, mostly diminishing beige head. The aroma is quite strong, lightly sour, moderately malty and lightly hoppy, with notes of cherries, spices, berries, caramel. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Extremely fruity, but too much on the sweet side. Medium to full body, average to lively carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitterness. Very good aroma, but as I have already said too sweet and sugary to fully enjoy it. so it is my least favourite from Abbaye Des Rocs, but however a more than decent beer.

0,33 bottle, bought at PreZBF Festival, Belgium.
Poured  dark rubby with a medium lacing off white head. Spicy aroma with cinnamon, cocoa, fruits like grapefruit, citrusses, orange peel. Agressive alcohol warming in the taste with fruity and cocoa tastes, gingerbread. Something unpleasant, unbalanced character in the flavor like aceton or something...

Bottle at The Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium, 19-02-10   Very rich nose to this beer, I actually get some oxtail soup along with some nuts and sweet malts. Pours dark brown, bit murky with an off-white head. Tangy in the mouth, and quite soft, its fruity and with a good bitterness throughout, very enjoyable.  A8 A3 F7 P4 Ov15  3.7

This beer has a very big flavor. A bit too sweet for my tase which brought its drinkability down. Also there is a lot of yeast floating around in this one. A bit more than I like to see. Also I dont want to feel the yeast clumps in my mouth, which you do with this beer.

Strong aroma of malty goodness, slight alcohol, and spice. This bottle pours a dark brown color with tons of yeast floating around, and a light tan head that vanished quickly for a Belgian beer. Initial taste of caramel, dough, and alcohol followed by a sweet after taste. This is a great Belgian strong ale that you should defiantly try if you have the opportunity.

750mL bottle from Knightly Spirits in Orlando.  Nice looking hazy amber brown pour with a sturdy medium beige head.  Sweet dark fruit and caramel malt aroma.  Balanced flavors of the same with yeast and spice mixed in.  Theres a background warmth but the alcohol is covered well.  The palate is creamy and it finishes up dry.  Seemed to get sweeter and sweeter as it warmed.  Definitely prefer it cold.

( 750ml bottle) This beer pours an absolutely beautiful ruby/rust/orange color, but only a 1 finger head. Lacing is impeccable. Nose of caramel, sweet malt, and hints of dark fruit. Alcohol is present as well, but subdued. Taste of caramel, sweet malt, mild hoppy bitterness that is exceptionally balanced with the malt almost where it isnt detectable, and it is sweet. Maybe slightly too much towards the sweet side, but very enjoyable. One more knock on this one was a relative lack of complexity. Mostly straightforward sweet, but I do like this in a beer so I found it very enjoyable. The alcohol at 10% is some of the most well hidden Ive come across. Mouthfeel is very creamy, coats my mouth and near perfect carbonation.
Dark amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of sweets, spice and yeast. A flavor of caramel, spice, sweets and yeast.

Beer compliments of Eduardo, from a 750ml vessel, poured a hazy deep amber color with a huge off white head. Light lacing. Aroma is light yeast and esters. Quite nice. Flavour is much of the same, with some caramel notes. Medium body. However, what I think makes this a top notch beer is its smoothness.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
Shared this fine Strong Ale with Everyones favorite Santa DrBayern, Brian the Beer Pimp, Santas Elf Celticbrew, Uncle Tom, and the Newbies, Lawyer Bob and The Boy Wonder Chris.
The aroma was somewhat sour.  that scared me!  It poured a dark copper color and was somewhat cloudy.  It had a very nice malty flavor and a sweet taste.  Very nice to drink.

Shared this one w/SkyCop32.  Pours a darkish red/brown. Aromas of spice, coriander, yeast, and alcohol. Flavor has an alcohol taste to it, mixed with a nice smokey dark fruit. Also has strong hints of spice.

750 ml bottle from City-Wide in South Bend.  Pours a deep, dark ruby-brown with a medium tan head with nice retention.  A ton of tan sediments in the glass- yeasty.  Aroma of dark and dried fruits (raisin, fig, plum), yeast, brown sugar, mild spices, cardboard, and cola.  Flavor is more complex, with notes of dark fruits, raisins, caramel, brown sugar, chocolate, mild spices, cream, and a few things I just cant place.  This is an unusual one that Ill have to revisit.  No trace of alcohol in the nose or mouth despite the 10% ABV.  Medium-full bodied, with a sweet, powdery, and almost tart mouthfeel.  Really unique.  Sweet finish.

Bottle; poured a reddish brown color with a creamy looking tan head.  Alot of floaties.  Aroma of dark fruit, caramel, yeast, alcohol, brown sugar, and candi sugar.  Complex and quality.  Flavor was very good and got better throughout the experience.  Dark fruit, sugar, sweet, caramel, yeast and fruit.  A really complex beer that is dangerously drinkable.  Great; cant believe it took me this long.

750ml from Total Wine & More Roseville. Pours a very chunky brown with a large beige head. Lots of chunks floating around at first... Aroma is mostly of brown sugar and malts, some peach and apricot toward the end of a whiff. Flavor repeats this pattern, but with the fruits turned up a notch. A lot of syrupy sweetness throughout. Pretty sweet, even for a Belgian. Nice mouthfeel, thick viscosity, good carbonation. Decent Belgian in the end. Overall, good to very good.

Pours a dark amber color with some quickly disappearing tan head and a lot of floating yeast.  Aroma is of sweet caramel and yeast.  Excellent flavor consisting of caramel, yeast, and a hint of chocolate completely hiding the 10% ABV.  This is an excellent Belgian Strong Ale from an awesome brewery.

Bottle.  Continuing my weekend Belgian tour, this one poured slow and dark cloudy amber brown with sediment. Foam head begins but simmers down quick with a light ring till almost the end.  As it warms it gets a little dry mouth feel.  Cola like aroma with light spice and yeast.  Light roast with an herb like spice hop note but mild and ALC very mellow.

750 ml bottle from Total Wine in Tustin ($7.99).  Pours a deep ruby/garnet color with a big three fingers of beige head.  Its cloudy with a huge amount of really big floaties.  With all the floating sediment, its not surprisingly that the nose has a lot of yeast but also includes caramel, spice (cinnamon), candied fruit, and other stuff.  Its a very complex aroma and Im at a loss to describe it much better.  Flavor is similarly complex with notes of caramel, chocolate, cherries, spice, and other rich flavors.  Its moderately sweet and nicely balanced.  Medium body with no alcohol presence and a sweet and tangy finish.  Excellent brew and perhaps the most yeast Ive ever seen in a bottle.

33cl bottle. Hazy, dark brown pour with light sediment.  Small, tan head and a little lacing. Aroma is milk chocolate, caramel, sugar, rum and some Belgian yeast. Very full mouthfeel. Brown sugar and spice in the flavour. Just a touch of booze in the finish. Very enjoyable.

Oak flavors all over everything.  Cherries also strong in both aroma and flavor.  Looks fantastic in the glass.  Hidden ABV and balanced start to finish.  A non-Belgian yeasty-ness pops up and keeps it from excellence.

330ml bottle.  Pours a deep chocolate brown with a thin dense biege head.  A sweet bready malt aroma with some funkiness.  Flavor is sweet dark fruit, caramel, earthy yeast and a light spice.  A nice creamy texture with well hidden alcohol.

The beer had a good usage of spice, dark malt and hops.  It had nice hints of caramel but overall the beer did not seem complete.  It was served a bit warm when I had it so that could have been a factor.

Pours a hazy very dark ruby/amber color with a thick frothy 1.5 finger head and chunks of yeast floating about. This is odd considering I left a good portion of the bottom of the bottle. Decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring, leaving sporadic spots of lacing.

Spicy estery aroma with hints of apple and pear. Also a bit of dark malt, subtle hops, alcohol and a weird chemical soapiness.

Peppery spice up front with some dark malt, light and dark fruit notes, candy sugar and slight alcohol warmth. Pretty smooth with the high ABV well masked. Complex and well balanced Belgian Strong Ale.

Poured brownish-red with a decent head, there were some yeast floaties in the beer.  Aroma was complex and fruity and the flavor was fruity and spicy with some cherry notes, alcohol does not come through for a 10% beer.  Awesome beer.

Good beer.  Dont know if I would call it a triple but it was tasty.  Pours a dark brown with medium white/tan head.  Aromas of peat moss, earth and fruit.  Flavors of fruit, sweet caramel and hints of chocolate.  Try it but dont expect it to be a traditional triple color.
TAP: opaque amber/brown pour, nice light beige head. Mild nut on the nose, creamy texture, tastes like a Rolo! Good stuff.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown, with a beige, frothy head. Frim body with a bit of sedimentation at the bottom of the glass. Aroma of raisins, malt, spice, clove, and a hint of hops. Medium body, with no trace of alcohol. Crisp, clean finish. Fantastic Belgian strong.

Pours a deep koka kola brown with a thick mocha head. Very strong nose of thick complex malt-fruit interactions. Sweet, malty flavor with a surprisingly stingy aftertaste- almost reminiscent of worchester(sp?) flavor. Definitely tons of flavor in this beer.
Fantastic. Hints of fruit and very satisfying. Would be higher, but its a little sweet/wine-esque for my taste.
Sweet soft cloudy mouth, makes it really feel like something a King, or an angel, would drink. Pours cloudy dark with a small head.

750ml Bottle: Aroma of chocolate, malts, nuts, wood, light caramel, light dark ripe fruit, figs, slight molasses, and some yeast. Poured brown/deep orange in color with a medium-sized, dense, tan head that lasted throughout. Cloudy. Slightly sparkling. Small, medium, large, and huge-sized particles throughout. Flavor is light to medium sweet. Tastes of malts, prunes, dark ripe fruits, light cocoa, slight toffee, slight caramel, nuts, figs, light wood, slight molasses, light raisin, slight brown sugar, and a slight hint of medicine. Medium to full body. Smooth texture. Average carbonation. Dark ripe fruit, toffee, caramel, raisin, fig, slight wood finish is clean and smooth.

Dark mahogany brown red, light head, floaties. Lovely aroma, orange marmalade, candi sugar, Turkish delight. Just as lovely of flavor. Deep, satisfying malty goodness, chocolate, caramel. Initial zip of carbonation lends a perfect mouthfeel. Fresh Brune is still the flag bearer, but this is not far behind, and very close with the Grand Cru, imo. In short, Abbaye des Rocs is the shit, one of a kind
bottle, dark brown with tan foam, aroma has a mix of scotch whiskey, oak, plum. and caramel, flavors of corn nuts, malty sugar, fried banana, good finish

A dark brown beer with a lot of big chunks of sediment & little head. Aroma was fruity, & chocolate. The taste was leather, sour fruit, chocolate, & a full bodied mouthfeel. I have had 2 other Des Rocs(Brune, Grand Cru) & this is not as smooth as those.
Colore marrone velato. Aroma dolce di malto, corposo, con caramello, non molto amara, e lalcol è ben nascosto. Una birra eccezionale sotto tutti i punti di vista!

2007 750 bottle.  Cork is wet and smells of sweet vinegar.  Pours a clear but  dark root beer brown with some expected floaties and a tall thick foamy beige head.  If it werent for the floaties it would be a 5.  Aroma of super sweet oxidized candi sugars with lighter nuances of age and slight fruit.  Flavor is quite rich, dark candi sugars with surprising depth, figs, dates, some red fruit, hard-candy sweetness, oxidized nicely, ha I was looking for a descriptor and I think LtDan found it for me, rhubarb.  Medium bodied with smooth dense fluffy carbonation, pillowy mouth-feel, leaves the mouth sticky.

Appearance:  A dark maroon/auburn, with a fizzy gathering of whiteness. The bottle and pour displayed big chunks of goodness.

Aroma:  Belgian yeast, strawberry  rhubarb pie filing , and other dark fruits.

Taste:  Bitter hops, dark fruit such as raisin, prune, and dried fig. Finishes bitter sweet.

Mouthfeel:  Feels almost syrupy, very coating.

Overall;  Not impressed. Sorry, its not bad, but its not spectacular.

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, malts, nuts, wood, light caramel, light dark ripe fruit, figs, slight molasses, and some yeast.  Poured brown/deep orange in color with a medium-sized, dense, tan head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Slightly sparkling.  Small, medium, large, and huge-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet.  Tastes of malts, prunes, dark ripe fruits, light cocoa, slight toffee, slight caramel, nuts, figs, light wood, slight molasses, light raisin, slight brown sugar, and a slight hint of medicine.  Medium to full body.  Smooth texture.  Average carbonation.  Dark ripe fruit, toffee, caramel, raisin, fig, slight wood finish is clean and smooth.  10%ABV is undetectable.

dark brow some yeast floaties, large smooth thick light brown head.
faint fruity, very subdued aroma, a bit flowery or soapy.
flavor is fantastic. loads of different notes which are blended so well together that the initial impression is some sort of WOW experience, it takes some concentration to single out all the flavors. raisins, licorice, several kinds of sugar, candi, brown. honey, ripe grapes, very faint cocoa, very faint vanilla like note, alc very well hidden, it doesnt come off as too strong or even alc strong, just lots of interesting flavor. spicy notes are here, but hidden below the main flavors, this works real well.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2009 750 mL shared into tulips. Pours a clear, deep brownish amber with a billowing, three-finger tan head that has okay retention and some good lacing. Outstanding aroma of rum-soaked cherries, rum-raisin gelato, caramel, Belgian yeast, candied dark fruits. Taste is a big letdown: initially it is a cascade of the flavors mentioned above but then turns for the worse: the alcohol becomes incredibly cloying and the sweetness becomes stale, overly redundant with mouthfuls of white sugar added to flat Diet Pepsi. It really is sort of gross. Maybe my bottle is skunked or something but unlikely since it is 10%. This really is not very good at all. Im very sad to say this, but I shared it with two other people and all three of us had to drain pour it. Jesus.

750ml bottle.  The beer pours a dark reddish/brown color with a thick tan head which dissipates pretty quickly.  The beer has a caramel, dark fruit and spice aroma, with a pretty decent amount of malt.

A fantastic  brew from Belgium. The alcohol is noticeable, though it does not detract too much even with it being 10%.

A hazy red/brown colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of bitters, dark fruits and some alcohol. The taste is bitter as well, sweet fruits, cherries with raisins. There are spices like coriander. The aftertaste is bitter and fruity.
Bottle. Dark brown pour. Sweet aroma. This was a great beer, flavor is very good.  Cant wait to try the other two Abbaye des Rocs beers.

Flaske: Ingen karbonering og tydelig surhed i duften tyder på en let infektion. Den fungerer så udmærket på de tydelige kirsebær, men det kan ikke være meningen for en mørk trippel. Bare ikke godt nok, men kan stadig drikkes. Skal rerates hvis jeg kan få en normal flaske.

Pours brownish orange, with a thick, enduring head and nice lacing. Aroma is of cherries, yeast, and modest alcohol. Some dark fruit flavors - raisins, plums, figs - and yes, more alcohol. Lively carbonation, creamy, silky smooth mouthfeel. Simply wonderful.

Bottle as shown. Pous a cloudy amber with a medium frothy light tan head that lasts awhile leaving behind good sticky lacing along the glass and large yeast flakes. The aroma is a sweet fruity malt with caramel and yeast. Medium mouthfeel with a dark fruit malt taste with caramel and brown sugar. Hides the alcohol well, a very good Belgian strong ale from Brasserie.
Bottle. poured a rich copper color. Nose was yeasty, a bit fruity, with a sour hint. Flavor is deep and full bodied notes of dark fruits. Complex flavors.Very nice.

Spectacular brew! Strong, but not overly abundantly laced with alcohol.  Very complex vinous brew with an excellent flavor. Strong flavors with complex esters, plum and grape flavors.  Keep this for a long time and this on ewill aprove with age.  Drink with a nice steak and mushrooms dinner.
Aroma of yeast and fruit .  Appearance is dark amber with a thick tan head.  Flavor of dark fruits and roasted malt.  Excellent beer.

Peculiar Pub: Rockin! Aroma is strong (maybe too strong), the fermented sugars and dark fruits, hops? are readily available. Pour is brown, some cloudiness, some sediment as well.  The taste is very balanced, medium complexity.  Fruits, honey/ caramel, malts flood the mouth, there is an alcohol finish which is balanced by the yeast and soft sugars.

Corked 750ml bottle, served in a tulip.  Hazy brown pour with large flakes of sediment and a two-finger thick head of fizzy tan foam that settled into a lasting cap.  Slippery lacing.  The aroma had alcohol-soaked raisins and plums, sweet candi sugar, and a bit of earthy yeast.  The flavor was sweet and boozy.  Tons of dark fruit along with sweet caramel.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and had a moderate amount of tingly carbonation.  A little too sweet for me.  Not bad.

Pours a swampy brown with large globs and (before I was forced to strain it) an pleasant off-white head and no lacing. Aroma is a,amazing - sweet, dark fruit, nothing like a triple, as the label had suggested. Lovely sweet fruity malting balanced against light hops opens up into sweet candy finish, overripe plums and baked apple, touch of spice. I actually had to strain this beer, as it was so thick with flocculent globs as to make it undrinkable - it had a thin pudding-like texture. So I strained it, and the body has decent carb with a thin but coating mouthfeel. Very, very tasty but I wish I didnt have to lose a third of the mass to large gelatinous globs in my strainer. I will try and obtain another sample for rating.
Very delicious.  Poured dark orange with a nice frothy head.  Nice chunks of yeast throughout.  Flavors were dark cherry and chocolate.  Very nice!

Poured a very murky brown. not as dark as most strong dark ales.
nice lacing, poofy head falls apart slowly.
Smells of hot dog water and cat food.
Smell is not this beers strong suit.
Taste is very similar to St. Bernardus 12. Very rich and nutty, but not too big that the yeast isnt present. The yeast on this one puts off some great esters. Notes of dark stone fruits, brown sugar, and clovy spice.
Not cloying at all, good balanced mouthfeel, not too sweet, not too dry, just very pleasant.

750ml bottle.  This one was funky strait out of the gate.  Nose was like hotdog water, cat food and bbq sauce all rolled into one.  Flavor was nice though, sweet with some candied dark fruits.  I think we had an old bottle, this brew was an enigma.

With great thanks to HogTownHarry. Ive a feeling that this has 4 years ageing on it! Appearance: Brown body with HUGE floaties, simply huge. Medium off white head. Aroma: Sweet and sour, bitter and caramel, very contrasting. Flax seed and dark grape with spices and earth. Flavour: Lumpy due to flecks! Caramel and deep dark Christmas fruit cake, almost sickly, thick and chewy with a long long malty fruit finish.

Sample at La Chatelaine. The beer is a murky ruddy brown color with a medium tan head that recedes slowly. Rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark fruits and malt, plus notes of caramel and yeast. The finish is fruity with yeast and earthy malt left over. Good all around.

11.2 ounce bottle from  Bruisin Ales. Pours a dark browinsh red color with floaties, some of them on the larger side. Medium creamy head with a medium body. Good retention and lacing. Aroma is caramel, bread, dark fruits, candi sugar and spices. Taste is brown sugar, caramel, raisin, dates, candi sugar, bread and yeast. Full bodied.

750ml bottle (One Pint Pub, Helsinki, Belgian Weeks 2009)
Deep brown, small tight head. Floaties and sinkies. Sweet fruity bubble-gum aroma. Very soft palate, carbonation low. Loads of tingly hops and a pile of sweet ginger cake. Plenty of sweet malty body. Finish is creamy and ginger cake. Covers alcohol well - its potent, but not actually strong. Some rubber later, which is the only drawback. Expect this to be excellent if left to age a couple of years.

Crushed with Jakebra.  Excellent nose of pears, apples, and other lovely fruits.  Flavor is a little subpar.  I like the guy who described it as some wet cardboard.  Right on.  Finish leaves the tongue sand-paper dry which isnt pleasant either.  Its not bad, but not great.

In the words of a good friend (who provided the bottle), this beer pwns. Place this in a class of megabeers.  Intensely yeasty, thick with flavor notes of what might have been molasses and (carefully) richly fruit-sweet.

Bottle @ The Trappist, Oakland, CA. Pours adark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a malty spicy yeasty aroma with some hints of dark ruit. Sweetish malty spicy yeasty flavor. Has a warming sweetish malty spicy finish with some hints of dark fruit in the aftertaste.

Tastes like raisins, wet cardboard, yeast, and hot alcohol. Lively carbonation and sticky sweet aroma. I love lambics, but dump-another-bag-of- candi-sugar-in-the-fermentation-tank style Belgians do nothing for me. Not worth another try.

Bottle, purchased at Stateline @ the De/Md border.  750ml bottle.  Pour is deep brown with generous amounts of yeast and other sediments.   Could be the best pour ever seen, which increases overall impression.  Mouth is medium to full,  in no way boozy.   Sophisticated and refined.  Flavors are complex, inviting and warming, dark fruits, earthy, and yeast.  A drink fit for the Gods of Gods (Rating = 4.85)
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 Bottle. Pours dark brown with a ton of sediment. Aroma is dark fruit/prune. Taste is great - complex, and hides the alcohol reasonably.

Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA.  This is one of the better Belgian Strongs Ive had, although it seems like the category should be something else.  Anyway, nice flavor combo of ripe fruits and spice.

Pours a dark rusty brown with a tall beige head. Delicious caramel, with nuts, bready Belginan yeast and some very ripe citrus fruits in the aroma. Very delicious flavor as well. Some over-ripe fruits, nuts, and spices combine very well with the sweet caramel malts to form a very nice balance. The creamy texture really slides down and hides the alcohol well. Great beer with a lot of the best parts of the Belgian styles.

2007 bottle at Kulminator. Dark reddish brown with a stable tan, creamy head. Yeasty, fruity cellar aromas and flavours with hints of spicy vegetables. Full-bodied. Noticeable alcohol. Very complex, maybe not a personal favourite, but quite unique.
Bottle from Total Wine in Roseville, CA. Poured a brown color with the sweet smell of carmel. Tasted of carmel and dark fruits. No hop taste in this one!! Quite impressive.
33cl Bottle from Hopduvel in Gent good beer. brown beer with small foam,  sweet soft taste touches of caramel and. medium alcohol taste
Bottle. Nutty brown body, with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet (caramel), alcohol. Flavor is sweet from the caramel, dark fruits and alcohol. A nice beer
Brown in color with a mediocre head, very cloudy.  Taste is malty sweet and has fruity flavor and has some alcohol taste.

Dark amber beer with the usual, annoying Abbaye des Rocs floaters. Big and lasting off-white head. The aroma has some caramel, malt and dried fruits, but also chalk, earth and old yeast. Flavour is caramel, dark sugar and dried fruits, with some warming/near-hot alcohol. Great big mouthfeel, and lasting and pleasant fruity, vineous aftertaste

The elixir decants in a bronzy blush, bespeckled with curiously immobile chaff, and adorned by a tremendous lumpy ivory mane of astounding stamina. Marvelous fruit and caramel aromas invade my skull and enwreathe my conciousness with spice and rosemary... thrilling nectarous fragrances as consummate and exquisite as the ethreal flirtations of a nubile sylph. Each sip incites an ambrosial feast; I gorge myself on pineapple and creme brulee, gingerbread and honey... and flavors practically dripping with exotic perfumes of jasmine and incense. The libation concludes on a bawdier, sweet-throaty chuckle of cola, cognac and lime that impulsively French kisses into a giddy green raisin and macadamia aftertaste. The fluffy, juicy mouthfeel features a schnappslike alcohol nip, the dulcet sensation as supplely fluid and wickedly piquant as cunnilingus. A vivacious and bewitchingly seductive ale.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2015 Hazy and dark brown. Plenty of sweetness in aroma and flavour. Liquourice and slightly numbing clove and alcohol have a formidable presence in this one.

Bottle at home.
Brown with a light brown head, some lacings. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, roasted, dark sweet fruits, brown sugar, spicy notes). Flavor moderate to heavy sweet. Full body.
Purs a wierd murky brown color. Huge bread like aroma with fig, plum and some booziness. Flavor and palate consist of raisin, fig, prune, bread. also brown sugar and caramel
Ruddy brown with big white head.  Aroma of raisins and malt.  Flavor of dark fruit with a well balanced malt and hop combo.  Should age nicely.

Cloudy medium brown with big chunks of sediment.  Nice big light tan head that hangs around in a creamy layer.  A delightful aroma is sweet fruit and yeast.  Sediment is so thick it almost has to be chewed.  Plenty of alcohol is noticed.  Flavors are fruit, yeast, sugar and pepper.  This has a brandy feel to it.  There is a big zing but not a lot of carbonation.  Another wonderful beer from Belgium.

des Rocs is one of my favorite brewers and I was happy to finally see this beer on tap at Mugs.  Poured into a pint (which I was very surprised to see, not cause of glass but just because of so much beer) with no head. It is completely murky gelatin with junk floating around, as always from the bottle but even on tap, damn guys.  Aroma is all coriander, man I guess I forgot this was all damn coriander.  Its like Traquir Jacobite with just a Belgian yeast. Taste chugs right along with the coriander, which also takes on a tea aspect.  In the end there is a bit of yeast fruitiness.  Man, all coriander but still cool.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: scent of fermented fruit but lots of yeast.  tons of sediment floating in the glass.  I feel like I am about to eat a slushy.  taste is fruity with a sour finish.  some honey is present as well.  leaves a sweet taste in the mouth.  I will need to try this beer again and hope for less sediment floating in the glass.  it is a pretty good beer though.

Bottle. Dark brown pour with a light brown head.  Tried to pour clean but it came out completely full of sediment.  Aroma was dominated by yeast and chunks of protein.  Sweet malt flavor with a bunch of brown sugar and dark fruit.  I tasted a bunch of yeast but thats obviously because of the pour.  Good brew.  Almost strained it through one o my clean socks to clear it up.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 Bottle, Hopduvel.
Pours brown with a small beige head. Aromas are awesome, chocolate, coffee, toffee, banana, vanilla, ...
Mouthfeel is silky, velvety. Certainly not overcarbonated and flavor is only mildly bitter. Pouring the bottom sediment adds that yeasty bread aroma.
Very good beer.

Rerate: staranise

Do yourself a favor and if you see this beer, buy it and drink it.  This is my personal Holy Grail of beers. Everyone will have something that really does it for them and this is mine.  Honestly, this is almost entirely about the taste. It doesn’t pour particularly well, and there’s always sediment floating around.  Not a particularly great head to it, usually small if poured correctly.  Now to the flavor - wow.  There’s nothing else to say. Now, to be fair, I like sweet.  Honey, fruit, candy, no noticeable bitterness and the alcohol is very well hidden.  Certainly not a quantity beer, but a fine choice when you’re looking for something special.
Pours burnt caramel brown with a halo of a tan head. Nose is dark fruits and caramel. The flavor is quite the same with a lot of ripe fruits. Smooth on the palate and clean finish.

Style and Glass: Belgian Strong; trappist, tulip, tumbler
ABV, Volume & Calories: 10 % in 25.4 fl oz. estimated at 400C
Purchased at: Canals Burlington, NJ

Aroma: very nice, cherry, chocolate, wine, sediment, moss. 9 out of 10.

Visuals: Gusher (like all Brasserie Des Rocs). nice label design and packaging, brown, murky, chunky with sediment, thin brown head, sticky lace. 5 out of 5.

Taste: unbalanced, pure malt, syrupy, no hops, low strength, medium craft. 8 out of 10.

Palate: medium quality, smooth texture, short fruity finish. 4 out of 5.

Overall: Very much like iced tea. Alcohol is almost unnoticable, not a repeat, not a favorite, low value, medium craft. 16 out of 20.
Pours a hazy amber with tan head. Aroma is heavy sweet nuts and fruit. Flavor is candied sugar and malts. Very sweet.  Body is creamy and carbonation is fair.

Amber/brown pour, huge white head, and huge amounts of lacing.  Aroma is of apples, candied sugar, yeast.  Flavor is of a typical Belgian Strong Ale - dark fruits, candied sugar, bread/cookie, and almost no bitterness.  Great brew.

Bottle from Whole Foods. Hazy dark brownish in color. Sweet candied dark fruit aroma. Some banana in the nose as well. Sweet flavors. Some roastiness and spices. Dark fruits and yeast. Alcohol is well hidden.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2008 Ruby-Mahogany with a large, yellowish, foamy head. Yeast sediment throughout the beer. Nose is quite a blend: very sweet with yeast, fruity jelly, caramel, some spice (possibly a little pepper). Sweet, fruity flavor, malts and yeast the dominant forces. Palate is a little foamy and too carbonated, but long lasting. A nice beer, perhaps best for desert.
Bottle: Hazy red colour, with a nice head. Aroma of sournes,citrus ,fruity,some yesatynes too. Flavor is fruity mouth feeling, nice medium body,medium fruity/citric finish.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2010 I had the Grand Cru last night, which was excellent, but Id be hard pressed to pick a winner between that one and this one. This pours a reddish-brown color, with just a slight haze to it and a nice off-white head. Aroma is a lot of fruits, plums, cherries, figs as well as some candy sugar. The flavors are tangy and tart with yeast and lots of the same fruits in the aroma as well as a zesty floral presence. Nicely done.

There is no doubt that this is a world class beer.  Pretty damn dark wtih a serious aroma of dark dried fruits, sweet malts and some honey.  Taste is sweet and rich with a nice delicate balance of malt, fruit, yeast and syrups(molasses and maple) Nice beer.

8/19/2008:  Whoah, I almost lost this one on the counter after opening it as well.  The beer starting foaming up and out of the bottle right after the cap was popped off.  Luckily I had a glass ready this time and only lost a drop or two...  Brasserie des Rocs Triple Impériale Belgian Special Dark Ale has an opaque, deep chesnut color with reddish hues.  There is a beautiful rise of bubbles to the surface to create a dense, lofty, and rich honey-colored head.  The aroma boasts fruity rich caramel, dark fruits, a touch of chocolate, and sugary raw honey.  Wow, what a great flavor.  It is sweet and rich and packed full of complexities that are hard to even identify individually.  There is definitely a lot of sweet, perfectly caramelized malts and candi sugar, cooked fruits including dates and raisins, light molasses, dark honey, a touch of vanilla, and a substantial port-like quality.  So good!  The body is thick and sticky.  This is a very impressive beer 
1 pint 9.4 fl. oz. bottle (10% Alc./Vol.; Best before end 2008) from ross via trade.  Thanks buddy!  Rating #494 for this beer...
Sour citrus hops raisons and dates. The malt is mostly grainy, almost wheaty. Smells like wheat and lemon.  Soapy yeast. Hops are the strongest flavor.

33 cl, bbe 2009. Hazy, dark red-brown color. Huge, bubbly head lasts forever with a nice meringue of lace. Unexpected aroma similar to a big American Strong: earthy molasses, orange-grapefruit, caramel, cocoa, light vanilla-oak and coffee. Flavor is a great mix of the same with some additional notes of raisin, brown sugar, whiskey, and more oak and caramel. Medium body is just a little too frothy, but well-dried and tingly with alcohol.

Bouteille 330ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. Dee couleur rouge-brune et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (raisins, prunes, agrumes, petites notes de dates, de pommes et de bananes), malté de caramel toffee sucré aux notes rôties, léger de sucre bonbon et de pain avec des notes de chocolat, d’épices (cannelle, clou de girofle), de houblon herbeux et d’alcool doux. Ronde-moyenne en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture crémeuse. Goût de levures fruitées (raisins aux notes vineuses, moyen de prunes, léger d’agrumes, notes de dates et de cerises, traces de pommes et de bananes) accompagné d’un moyen goût épicé (clou de girofle, léger de cannelle) lors de l’entrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de caramel toffee assez sucré et aux notes rôties, léger de sucre brun, de sucre bonbon, de pain et avec des notes de chocolat noir puis en finale on note également la présence d’un léger goût d’alcool un peu réchauffant ainsi qu’une moyenne amertume de houblon herbeux et de levures épicées (petites notes de poivre doux) aux notes boisées et terreuses. Post-goût long et aux notes sèches, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux, de levures fruitées (moût de raisins vineux et de prunes, notes de zest d’agrumes et de moût de cerises) avec un léger goût d’alcool.

Pours an orange/brown with lots of floaters and a thin head.  Sweet candy sugar, raisin, plum, orange citrus, cherries, brown bananas, honey, and biscuits.  The carbonation keeps the beer from being to heavy.  Lightly sweet and quite complex.  The alcohol is well hidden.

11.2 oz bottle. This first time I bought this beer it was in a 750 ml bottle and it erupted upon opening. To be fair i gave it a second chance coming from the smaller bottle. Moderate malt notes of roasted, nutty and caramel, light hop and yeast notes of herbs and earth, with date and wine in the background. Head is large, frothy, off-white with some peices in it, has good lacing and is fully lasting. It looked like an ice cream float each time I took a sip. Color is hazy, but sparkling, brown. Flavor is lightly sweet and moderately acidic to start and finishes lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, oily, and has a lively carbonation. The chunks in this beer are a bit frightening, but beyond that it’s an excellent Belgian Strong.
33cl, exclusive brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex, balanced, hazy, small head, very good brew, the best beer of Abbaye des Rocs, drink cold
Bottle at Kulminator, Antwerp. Pours dark brown with a medium lasting beige head. Aroma is quite sour with dark fruits as the dominating note. Flavour is spicy with dark berries and cane sugar.

Bottle 11.2 oz Bangor ME 08’. 

Bottle erupted when opened.  Settlement came out in the head and was suspended in the beer when poured into a tulip.  Sweet malts, honey cake, buscuits, over ripe bananas, and dyactel.  Well done tripel w/ balanced alcohol bite.  Very enjoyable.

750ml Bottle. Pours brown with sediment particles and thin head. I didn’t like the smell at first, reminded me of some low quality brews I’ve previously thrown away due to tons of added alcohol I just can’t stand. So I started with low expectations but the first sip changed all that. Aroma is mild and tasteful, a nice blend of honey, caramel, and fruit. Alcohol was barely noticeable. I just wish it had a longer finish. Very well done.

(11.2oz bottle from Whip-in with Ana P at home on June 26, 2008) Pours a malty orange/brown color, very carbonated at first, into a small snifter.  Head active, but dissipates, leaving no lacing.  Aroma is light, spice/caramel, maybe toffee/molasses.  Burnt sugar, etc.  Taste is sweet and salty on the tip of the tongue.  My mouth is still watering from the saltiness... its almost astringent.  Palate is dry, with a sweet alcoholic cloud lingering at the back of the tongue for a while after the brew goes down.  Alcohol noticeable, but well accompanied by the malty tripel-ness.  A great tripel!

Probably my favorite Belgian. An abbey ale with dark sugar. Pour dark cloudy brown with tons of suspension and sediment. Large tan head that last a while. Good dark sugar, belgian yeast aroma. Great flavor of dark sugar fruit, and belgian yeast. Incredibly smooth for a 10%. You cant even tell. Very enjoyable. Flavorful, smooth finish.

75cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa). Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head that leaves little lacing on the glass. Aroma: ripe dark fruit, sour citrus, grass, straw, apple, complex spice. Flavor is sweet and sour with tang and hints of coffee, vanilla and banana. Very different tripel but not unpleasant. Complex Belgian ale.

In a bottle from World of Beer, Westchase.  This is an excellent, albeit strong beer.  It smells strongly of whiskey and apple.  Pours a dark brown with notes of medicine, caramel, sugar, and finishes with brown sugar flavor.  No lace, but lots of carbonation.  Interesting beer.

My favorite from the brewery.  Must buy the 750 for some reason though.  Bottle.  Pours a dark brown nectar body with a thin tan head.  Aroma and flavor is loaded with spices, clove, sweet malt, caramel malt, etoh, toffee.  Wow this is incredible!

750 ml bottle given to me by rebelbeerguy for  Christmas. WOW this is the chunkiest, most yeastful floating having beer I have ever seen. Seriuosly if beer has to be labeled with pulp or extra pulp added this one should have a warning reading solid floating chunks in every sip. Poured a thick floatie filled brown with a large light beige head. Aroma is phenomenal, tons of sweetness, lots of fruitiness and yeast rounded out with caramel and toffee malts, exquisite. Full mouthfeel and you dont even notice the chunks of sediment as you swallow this bad boy, finishes rather refreshing and light for how chunk filled it is. Flavor is sweet with lots of dark fruit, toffee, brown sugar, and tons of yeast. This is some really nice stuff, time to get more.

Amber brown body with nice sized lacing slightly tan head.  Aroma was rich of cinnamon sugar and soem clove with a touch of spice.  Sweet brown sugar upfront with complex fruitiness. Finishes nice and smooth with flavours bursting out.  Rich and smooth.

Bottled. duff bought me this at Kulminator, Belgium. 
Ruby amber colour with big head. Cabbage, dark plum, prune and yeast in aroma. Very soft mouthfeel from the rich yeast chunks, with plum and prune most prominent, yet very sweet and potent, and traces of wood. The alcohol is very well hidden. Yet another solid ale from a great brewery!

The commercial description is right on when it talks about the enormous scale of flavors.  The dark fruit sweetness is the main player but their is some yeast and bitterness.  The flavors are just to strong for me but it is still a pretty good drink.  A very slow sipper

This bottle foamed up crazily when I opened it. Poured dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel and dried fruits. Flavor is sweet dark fruits with some caramel and spice. Nice mouthfeel, hides its alcohol well. Very good.

330ml Bottle from Hopduvel, Gent. Poured an opaque mahogany colour with no head. Aromas of raisins, prunes, caramel and yeast. Flavour was overwhelmed by an almost savoury yeastiness, tasting a bit like Marmite which clashed with the accompanying fruitiness and toffee. Warming alcohol finish. A bit too extreme for me.

Pours a cloudy ruby amber. Powerfully fruity aroma of cranberries, raisins and a bit of apple. The flavor brings out a tartness (not-quite-ripe strawberries) and a bitterness (mild grapefruit) that werent in the aroma - this ones all across the map, yet balances the flavor very well. Mouthfeel is nearly perfect - heavy, but not sticky and still well-carbonated. This isnt one Id pick up very often, but its complexity is interesting, and it drinks very well for such a fruity beer.

Caramelly, toasty aromas with a slight musty smell.  Pours cloudy amber with a solid white head that seems to be lasting as i let it warm a little.  Green raisons, very malty, hints of caramel, with some fruity flavors, fresh grapes.  towards the finish theres a very slight tartness, but finishes sweet and smooth.

Deep dark-red brown color,, with an creamy beige head. 
Aroma yeast, malt, some sweetness . Full body. Taste fruits, roasted malts, bittersweet chocolate, bit rum, good balanced in the finish with  hopsbitter. 
Alcohlic warm feeling.
NICE.

Bottled, thanks ante!  Cloudy brownish dark amber with creamy head. Estery pineapple aroma with some raspberries. Sweet and full bodied. Potent concentrated juicy flavours of strawberry esters, lingonberry and wood. Alocohil is fuelling the intesnity of the flavours, but does not disturb. A full flavoured very good beer. In fact nearly as good as their somewhat less strong releases which is a very good thing.

75cl bottle.   Deep brown color with a medium beige head and lots of chunks floating around.   Looks good disregarding all of the sediment, but when you give it a close look, its a little unsettling.   Winey aroma with tart cherries and pineapple, with  a caramelized sugar base.   The flavor is bursting with tart fruits that curb the intense sweetness at first, but seem to emphasize it before too long.   By the end of the glass, the sugar became cloying.   The body was pretty full, with good carbonation, but the protein chunks added a slight chewiness that became a bit much at the end.   I think that this would be a nicer beer in small doses without the chunks, but trying to drink a whole bottle as-is was almost impossible.   Definitely a let down after the other beers Ive had from these guys.
Poured a nice deep red/brown with a minimal head.  A little malty, a little fruity.  Creamy and smooth.  Nice beer.

Bottled. Pours out in a cloudy reddish brown colour, topped with a low white foam. Cherries, cumin, mild pepper, anise-seeds, leather and figs in the aroma. Figs, nutmeg, leather, black cherries and brown sugar in the flavour. Medium-bodied with a surprisingly light mouthfeel despite its strength. Long warming finish of dried oranges, cherries, milky chocolate and nutmeg. Quite tasty but I expected more from this one.

Bottle. Pours a dark hazy amber brown with small but lasting off-white head. Aroma is spicy with brown sugar. Dark fruits with spicy yeast and sweet brown sugar. Creamy full body. This is not as good as the other abbey des rocs Ive had but is still excellent.
Sweet and convincing beer that has a lot of flavors with a rare intensity. This dark Triple is like a "Duivel Bruin" from brewery Lembeek.

pours a bubbly clear dark red copper with high full light beige head and sediment at the bottom.  smooth sweet yeast aroma.  carbonated palate tingles the front, dry finish and aftertaste.  sweet front with caramel slight background some hard rock candy and dark fruit.  yeast presence, good full bodied and complex.
Thx for another great tasting, Kim (Beljohansen) !!!. Maroon, bubbly, short head, dried fruit, maltym yeast, very sweet.

Bottle. Low but lasting off-white creamy head. Hazy dark orange red body with big lumps of yeast sediments. Sour berries aroma with a spicy note. Flavor though is far from sour, its not even acidic, actually it is rather sweet and fruity with a low carbonation and a long sweet aftertaste. Would never have guessed on such a high alcohol percentage. Nicely hidden.

750 ml bottle from Total Wine. This bottle was a gusher. Pours a copper/brown with a quarter-inch of tan head that reduces to a couple centimeters. Nose is sour yeast, mellow oak notes, and apples. Similar flavors with dark fruits, caramel, candi sugar, and apples in the finish. Alcohol content is hidden well. Highly carbonated and medium-bodied. Good beer, although it gave me a slight stomach ache. Mustve been something I ate.

(330 ml bottle (best before end 09) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/portland/ target=blank>Downeast Beverage Co., cellared for 1 yr. after purchase) Soft and sweet...Gushed a little bit upon opening. Pours cloudy brownish amber with one finger of creamy, soft-looking biege head that recedes to about 1/4" and stays. Quite a bit of solids at bottom of bottle. Aroma of candyish malt, dark fruits and brown sugar. Mouthfeel is buttery soft and luscious. Thin sheets of lacing on inside of glass melt away quickly. Flavor is big and sugary - brown sugar and candy malt sweetness with touches of dark sweet fruit. Well-integrated alcohol presence. Quite elegant and tasty.

Has an absolutely wonderful fruity smell .... some nice head on the pour.... is very complex, crazy! (fruit,rum,raisins,grape, xmas bread etc...) ... quite fizzy for a belgian strong ... a true joy to drink .. Bring On The ROCS!
Brown color with thick tan head.  Caramel malt, spices, and belgian yeast on the aroma.  Similar body with the addition of dark fruits.
deep brown pour with a decent head. sweet aroma of dark fruits and alcohol. flavor was sweet and rich with the alcohol well hidden. very nice.

I bought this to celebrate Monday night( football). Into my tulip it goes, with a creamy inch and a half of foam. It is a beautiful cherrywood amber in color. Clumps of lace cling to my glass. 

The aroma of this beer is incredibly rich. It is of cinnamon, figs, brown sugar, and rum cake. The taste is no letdown. Raisins and figs combine with ripe cherries upfront. Nutmeg and cinnamon, and banana bread with nuts in it round out the flavors. Soak all of this in dark rum, and you start to get an idea as to what this tastes like. The alcohol is slightly noticeable. 

The mouthfeel is very thick and bubbly. The drinkability is off the heazy. Get some.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-05-2005 00:40:11

Pours a lovely color that seems to range from orangey red browns to purpley red browns. Creamy grey tan head that lingers well and has some nicely long lasting lacing. nose is a nice combination of roasty bread crust, caramally sweetness, with notes of raisins, prune, and othered dried fruits. Dark fruits make a substantial contribution to the flavor profile pairing well with the bready yeasty characteristics. Slight metallic notes are acceptable in the profile as well as some spicey flavors, and just enough biotterness to really round it out. Finish lingers quite a while, with some very pleasant roasty bready characteristics followed by some almost tart berry notes. Body is somewhat fluffy and creamy with a perfectly soft carbonation. If it werent for the two inches of yeast at the bottom of the 750, this would be a nearly perfect beer.

Pours a dark brown with a nice thin tan foamy head. Aroma of roasted malt, yeast, with a hint of citrus. Taste is very sweet, carmel, roasted malt. Did I say this was sweet!!! nice carbination. This is really a nice brew .....a little sweet!
Hazy brown with medium head. Sweet aroma with notes of roasted malt, ripe fruits and caramel. Flavor pretty much the same. Ends sweet.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, alcohol, fruit, orange, citrus. Flavour is alcohol, dried fruits, cellar notes, orange, citrus, yeast. Nice beer.
Bottle at Kulminator. Dark dark brown - offwhite head. High malty, very aromatic, sweetness, high chokolate, spicy, honey sweetness, raisins, mysli, flowery, a bit strange spicy. Very nice !!

750 ml bottle from West Lakeview, Chicago.  Best of date 2007.  Dark brown color with a little red tint and large creamy off-white head and nice lacing, pretty chunky and a lot floaters but not as bad as the brune.  Aroma has a large alc presence, kind of like a cross between a whiskey and abbey quad with toffee, bourbon, distinct plum, sour red fruit, really complex and the booziness isnt too much.  Dark fruit flavor with aged alc, some dough, yeast, plum and grapiness, some toasty bread, flavors actually overpower noticable alc presence.  Medium body and creamy.  Very nice, complex and warming strong with hints of barrel, perfect on a night like this.

Pours mahogany with a rich, off-white head.  Aromas of banana and apricot with a hint of hops.  Extremely complex flavor with prune, caramel, cola, coffee coming in succession.    Full body, long finish.

Bottled at Kulminator, Antwerp.
Dark brown with a white head.
Typical, yeasty Abbaye de Roc and a sour vinegar-flavour, like from pickles.

(on bottle, thanx to thewolf) Phenomecal aroma here. Full of cranberries, blackberries  on one hand; liqourice and rye on the other. Even got some sour ale notes in there too. Perky mouthfeel and a tatse of barrels, quite light infact. In  the tatse, are the berries supplementet by canesugar and melasses. The finish combines all the above with strawberries. Very complex, very easydrinkable, very good.

Bottle (75 cl) at Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium. Dark with creamy white head. The typical perfumy and spicy Abbaye des Rocs aromas are there, but also a strange vinegar character. Medium bodied and very smooth. Slightly sour finish.

Dark berry/ruby color with tan head and lots of yeast sediment. Smells a little maltier that the Grand Cru or Brune. The flavor is bland upfront, then it hits you with a strong caramel malty flavor with dark fruits and brown sugar. I like this much better that the Brune/Grand Cru. It also has a very good body and carbonation with slight bitter finish. Yum!

Bottle. Bit hazy amber-red colour. Aroma is a bit sour with dark malt and bread. Soft mouthfeel. Nice well toasted maltiness, good caramel sweetness with a comfortable mild sourness, spices and some dark fruits in the flavour.

Bottle @ thewolf tasting.
Bought @ Wohlenbergs, Sønderborg.
Pours a wonderful clear red amber with a medium creamy beige-brown head. Sweet aroma, lots of dried fruits, some tarty berries and good caramel. Fine, creamy mouthfeel with lots of nice little bubbles. Flavour is soft, berries, superbly balanced between tart and sweet. Really complex and wonderful.

Pours dark brown with thick, lasting one finger head.  Aroma off toffee and yeast with some candies fruits and citrus notes.  Taste much the same.  Full mouthfeel.  Extremely smooth.  Delicious.  Seems much more like a quad than a triple.

Bottle. A hazy, golden-orange beer with the typical Abbaye des Rocs floaties. Dried fruits, alcohol, malty sweetness and some spices in the aroma. The flavor is sweet and spiced, with dried fruits as well. Sweetish, full-bodied beer. I would like the floaties to go away, but its sure one hell of a beer. (080118)

bottle - Pours dark brown with a huge lingering head, but the many large floaters makes it not a terribly attractive beer though.  It smells of malt and yeast with a touch of dark fruit.  The flavors are mainly sweet caramel malt, candy sugar, and yeast.    The 10% abv is truly buried under all that sweetness.  It is perhaps a little too sweet, but still very enjoyable.

I really thought the bartendress brought me the wrong beer when I took a whiff and then a sip of this beer.  It is not like a Triple in any way, but I guess its "imperial," so you can do what you want with it.  This beer is cerealy and sweet, which is a flavor I tend to avoid/dislike, but in this case it is carried off reasonably well.  Still, mixed feelings on this one and I wouldnt call it a favorite of mine.

It poured a muddy brown with a medium head.  Aroma is very malted-milk-ball-like, with a lot of grainy sweet cereal smell to it backed with some fruitiness.  Taste was similar, with some additional complexity in the malt flavor becoming clear after a few sips and after it warmed a bit.  There was no spice flavor that I usually associate with triples, and the fruitiness that was present was pretty minimal and confined to the finish of this beer.  The beer in no way tasted alcohol-y, particularly for a beer with 10% ABV.  Mouthfeel was smooth and good.

Im a bit conflicted; this beer was not true to style (as I understand the style), exhibited a flavor that I usually dislike, but managed to pull it off in a way I thought was kind of pleasant.  So I will recommend this beer.

I had a bottle of this at The Room in Miami Beach, FL.

Bottle. Hazy orange body with floaters. Medium, short lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet malt, dry fruit, candy sugar, caramel and alcohol. Flavor as aroma. This is nice, a bit to sweet and quite hot (warming alcohol.) Somehow a feel this is not exactly as complex as a few other great brews from this brewery. Its no trippel for sure and I feel the brune is a lot more complex. Not bad, just not fantastic.

a little mixed on this one... yes its delicious, but too sweet. Heavy on caramel, carmelized onions, sweet ripe fruits, and the finish is very interesting. However, too sweet for me, would love with creme brulee!

Poured a dark reddish brown with a tan head. Aromas of dark fruits and sugars. Flavors of raisins, figs, sugar, caramel and yeast. Very sweet. Creamy mouthfeel with mild carbonation. I was slightly disappointed, expected more.
12oz bottle, pours dark reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma of dark fruits and yeasts. Taste is the same. Finishes sweet with taste of yeast

Provided by and tasted with ilovedarkbeer. Aroma is seeded fruits (dates) with clove and cinnamon and some dark sugar. Moderate yeasty smell out back. Creamy, light brown head upon pouring covering an dark amber body. Good lacing. Some pretty large particles floating around too. Taste is excellently well balanced with some nice sweetness. Very yeasty finish. Creamy mouthfeel, but fizzy carbonation. Very nice, but light, alcohol presence on the finish. Good beer!

Finally a beer for Abbaye des Rocs that lives up to its hype. Pours a deep dark brown reddish color with a medium to large sized brown cream colored head. Nose is sweet and mostly of dark fruit and belgian candi sugar. Taste is sweet, fruity, yeasty, acidic, green, and has a great lasting warming finish. A really great belgian ale.

Dark amber pour with plenty of sediment and off-white head.  Huge beautiful aroma:  lemon, grapefruit, lime, raisins, clove, plum, apple, brown sugar, strawberry, candied sugar, molasses, and a bit of alcohol.  Flavor contains sweet dried fruit, strawberry, belgian yeast, candied sugar, lots of cola notes, and not much bitterness.  Still, the flavor is dreamlike.  Palate is smooth and creamy, slightly sticky,  with a dry finish.  Im halfway through the bottle, and I can already say that this ranks as one of the top Belgian Strongs Ive had the pleasure of drinking.

Sept. 2006 - Beautiful dark brown pour with a centimeter thick head which lasted and laced the glass.  Aroma was sweet candy and dark fruits...very strong.  The mouthfeel on this was superb...creamy and thick.  The flavor was maybe a tad overly sweet from candied sugar, plums.  Very warming beer, just maybe a tad overly sweet without any real hoppy bitterness to balance.

Very disappointed with this one... Aroma is good with hints of fruit, caramel, and it is very sweet.  Also, it is a beautiful beer... a dark ruby/brown color.  It may look delicious, but the flavor was of way over sweet caramel, fruit, malt, iron, and a little alcohol.  I couldnt finish it.

1 pt. 9.4 oz. bottle.

Mahogany color with a big frothy head. Cotton candy caramel sweet earthy nose with some oxidation. Medium thick body with a foamy, but soft mouthfeel. Good taste is mildly sweet with burnt caramel and an earthy molasses flavor. . Alcohol is well cloaked. Best by 2007 on label. 62206
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Sampled at joebrews weekly beer tasting seminars at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St. Paul, MN. Pours a semi-clear dark brown brew with a thick off-white head that has some good retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel malt, some yeast, earthy spice a touch of chocolate and coriander. Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation with flavors of semi-tart caramel malt, yeast, and dark pitted fruits. Finish is slightly metallic from the high alcohol with aftertaste flavors of tart caramel malt and yeast.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma has some slght spice, a lot of yeast, chocolate, and sweet peach too.  The taste is very sweet with peach, chocolate, caramel, and a nice dry yeasty finish.  Quite different than most tripels Ive tasted, but still good nonetheless.

Fruity sweet aroma, cloudy amber pour.Slight caramel/syrup, "pit fruit" taste (peach/apricot). Nice level of malt and yeastiness, slightly bitter finish balances things out. Maybe a bit too much sediment (or I poured in too much of it).
Pours brown with a tan head. Very nice aroma of dark fruit and Belgian yeast. Nice sweet and slightly tart flavor.  Alcohol is well hidden. Very good stuff.

Poured into a Chimay goblet. Burgundy body and a creamy tan head. Classic Belgian lacing. Dozens of yeast chunks are floating around, as is expected from Brasserie Des Rocs.

Aroma is very Belgian with lots of yeast and dark fruity esters.

Taste is of dark fruits, a certain spiciness, doughy yeast, toffee, apple. Some booziness that mellows out with time.

Great carbonation, prickly and fine. Rich but easy to drink. Drinkability takes a bit of a hit from all the big yeast floaties.

Had this at Joes farewell tasting at the Cellars.  Dark coppery brown pour with with a light mocha colored head.  Dark fruit on the nose along with some sweetness (maple or molasses).  Toffee and maple as well as dates and other sweet dark fruits in taste.

I generally dont like Tripels, but this is far from a normal one.  Instead of the light, citrusy flavors like most Tripels, this one is much darker with more malts and darker fruits flavors.  Immensely complex, and amazingly flavorful.
Amazing!  This beer is a must-drink for fans of any dark beer.

Mmmmm delicious!!!!  This beer has been one of my all time favorites for quite some time.  Instead of the overpowering corriander and orange peel most tripel or beers of this style exude, this boy exudes chocolate, brown sugar, anise.....lots of anise and a hint of smokiness.  Great beer.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: [Bottle] Pours dark amber with a big light tan head. Aroma is quite sweet, chocolate, liquorice and malt. Taste is chocolate, grape, some malt with a slight bitterness on the finish. Medium-thick mouthfeel. Pretty good stuff.

[1002-20071224] 1pt9.4floz. Mild tomato and beef aroma with a bit of fruity Belgian yeast, almost like Classico pasta sauce. Murky, dark brown amber body with a big medium-lasting foamy yellow head. Flavour has a little smoky fruit and mild tobacco leaf. Medium-full body is smooth. Very interesting, alcohol is hidden.

Out of the bottle.  Poured a brown color.  Nose of dark fruit, sweet and inviting.  Taste was rich, full of perfumy sweetness, ripe fruit, brown sugar.  Almost caught some berry essence at times.  Had this and the Brune at the same time.  I was shocked by how similar the taste was.  Both good, but almost interchangeable.

Hmmm, poured from a 11.2 FL oz bottle. A dark golden brown color. Sweet woody syrub smell. Tastes sweet, spicey, woody, maple, caramel, brown sugar, creamy, and more. Lively carbonated, but i lite it, makes a very tasty and strong beer very easy to drink, unbeleiveable easy, it just disappears down. Is it me, or is there a lot of pulp? Sweet and spicey finish, alcohol is very well hidden. A GREAT BEER!

Bottle pored into a Duvel tulip glass dark brown with a nice one finger worth of lace and a few yeast particles floating around. This one has a great aromas of Belgium yeast and caramel along with a light dark fruit in the background. This ale has a medium creamy body and a nice tingle on the tongue. Flavors of toffee and sweet caramel along with sweet fruit not much bitterness in this one but it does have a light spice presence.
Good thing this thing has floaters it causes you to sip it and really enjoy it. LOL   Not the first Belgium that I have had floaters in

Dark copper color with a hint of haziness, nice lacing from the light tan head. The aroma is really strong with darkish fruits, I imagined cherries, figs, and raisins. Really nice. The flavor had the fruits, but mixed with a splash of cough syrup and a mild alcoholic burn on the backside.
ruby pour with khaki lacings.  malts and dried fruit on the nose.  pretty thick with mostly fruits on the palate.
Very fruity beer, with hints of dark fruits in both the flavor and in the taste.  Fancy bottle, and decent beer.
