text: Pop the cap and out comes a wonderful aroma of dried fruits and spices. From the bottle it pours a dark cloudy amber with a huge head that laces nicely. Flavor is a wonderful sweet fruity taste with an alcohol burn. Theres a bit of tartness in the taste that is very nice. Very good.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Hazy copper pour, off-white head. Suspended bits of yeast throughout. Light aroma of sweet caramel and spices  a hint of clove. The flavor is full of spice and sweet caramel and a note of earthiness. There is a slight tartness. Medium body is smooth on the palate, syrupy in the aftertaste with a long finish.

Aroma of dark malts and fruits. Dark mahogany color with a coarse beige/tan head. Full bodied with coarse/creamy carbonation. The flavor is smooth dark fruits and malts. Spice is present and complex, but light. The finish still bursts with fruits. Not a great deal of bitter, but neither is it sweet. An excellent example of how neither sweet nor bitter has to dominate. Its fun to enjoy.
Pours a deep reddish brown with a nice creamy head.  Aroma is has elements of fruit and malt.  Nice malty flavor with a bit of spice and fruit with a flavorful finish.
Pours a reddish brown with a medium head that quickly reduces in size.  The taste is sugar, alcohol, and dried fruit.  There is a strong, warming finish.

Pours out a little head that falls into a very thin head thats almost gone. Very weak lacing thats barely noticeable. Smell is very sugary, like caramel. Kinda nice. The taste is very sweet, with dark fruit undertones. Mouthfeel is just fine, pretty good. I would drink this again, but it seems like I would like a newer beer and it would be even better.

Bottled. Deep ruby red colour, small off-white head. Aroma is caramel yeast, alcohol and slightly glueish. Flavour is alcohol, raisins, fruits and mildly glueish notes. Wellbalanced. The aftertaste leaves a lot of fruits and raisins.

(Bottled) Very hazy dark brown with a small, but lasting head. Lots of dark and dried fruit in the aroma with some malty sweetness. Grainy-malty, very dark-fruity flavor with bitterish hops and roastiness. Almost full-bodied with smooth carbonation. An enjoyable, lighter, yet a bit too sweet version of the regular Abbaye des Rocs. Doesnt change much with yeast.

Just like their Grand Cru, the glass is filled with suspended particulates that just dont settle. Active micro-bubble carbonation percolates upward, but the yeast particles just sit there. The head is massive and puffy, fading slowly to a tan film. The nose is very sugary, with candied orange, toffee, figs, plum, corriander and pear. Hardly any booze is detectable in the aroma. The flavour is insanely sweet and yeasty, with that bubblegum yeast, caramel and bouquet of fruits and herbal hops. Very nice velvety, full-bodied mouthfeel with gentle carbonation. The finish is not-so-dry and leaves a lingering candied fruits and well-hidden alcohol that is noticable only as a warming of the throat. Another dangerously strong ale.

This beer was dumped into a trappist glass and foams right up with a thick head that was reall sudsy looking. It has a redish brown color with massive suspended particulate matter with what looked like a ferris whell as the matter was swirling in a circular motion in the center of the glass, The aroma is nice and sweet with fruity malt and lots of cherry and mild hops. As you drink it you can feel the tingle of the particulate rush over your lips into your mouth. There is that nice initial bitterness with malt and cherry and the presance of booze. I personally enjoy the warming swet finish it has along the sides of my mouth.

Pours a darker amber color with an off-white head.  Aroma is of dark fruits, caramel malts, candied sugar, and some alcohol.  Flavor is pretty sweet with the candied sugar and dark fruits.  Finishes with a decent alcohol warming.  A pretty delicious brew.

bottle.  pours a deep dark burgundy with a cream head that wont go away and leaves plenty of lacing.  tons of floating yeast.  nose is spicy apples and pears, with dark fruits and some bready malt mixed in.  taste is spicy caramel with a deep fruit profile coming in as it sits.  good malty sweetness on the end, with a thick coating mouthfeel.  fairly full bodied with plenty of carbonation.  this is good stuff.  ill have to get some more of it.

Dark amber with nice, one finger head. Dissipated completely. Good lacing. Aroma is tart, sweet, and citrus. Very nice, full mouthfeel; non-fizzy. Taste is candy sweetness well balanced with maltiness. Hint of orange. Tastes like Happy:) One of my all time favorite beers.

Belgian Style Dark Ale.  .33L poured in a Chimay glass.  Murky, muddy, medium brown color, tan creamy head.  Aroma of dark rich malt.  Strong aromas of figs and dried fruit.  Distant aromas of baked beans cooked with brown sugar, cilantro, cumin, and bacon grease... Odd, although it tastes nothing like that.  Flavor is sweet and malty.  Flavors are a bit roasty in the finish.  Heavy bodied and a slow sipper.  Overall: A super tasty, heavy hitter.

11.2 oz bottle, BB end of 2008.  This was was really excited about leaving the bottle.. when I got a glass under it, it poured beautifully with a deep plummy-caramel complexion and a short, creamy cap of medium tan head.  The aroma picked up caramel, darker fruits, and toffee for a great dark, sweet base.. mild nutmeg, dried figs, and just the faintest banana accent.  The flavor was quite sweet overall with drawn caramel, buttery toffee, and darker fruits accented by figs and herbal bitterness.. tart fruit skins hit right at the back.  Creamy and rich on the palate with high carbonation.. so thick, though, that it moved slowly, and the carbonation made the flavor pop on every square inch of the mouth.. a little sour on the back end, which somehow made this a touch refreshing.. damn near a 5 on the palate.  Just an excellent beer!

750mL bottle.  Murky dark brown-orange with a very large rocky off white head.  Vinous aromatics with spicy, bready accents.  Dark alefruit, figs and dates, up front.  Apple, grape flavors with a turning fruit sweetness.  Slight metallic character with a bready caramel and phenolic gestalt.  Lingering spiced sweetness in the finish, some toffee.  Mouthfeel is rich and heavy.
11.2 ounce bottle purchased at Case & Keg Beer World Boca Raton, FL at $4.00

I never found this bottle in Europe, finally found it at Saloon on U Street, WashingtonCloudy brown color. Very sweet Belgian Strong Ale, malty, full bodied, with sweet caramel, not much bitter, and the alcohol is well hidden. Very good, but I expected more complexity and character.

Bottle, thanks to shp555.  Pours a reddish brown, with a medium sized head, and of course a couple particles here and there.  Aroma is a bit strange.  I dont think the yeast smells right in this beer, its almost as if a wine expired in this beer.  As it warms, that subsides a litte and theres some cinnemon, chocolate, pears, plums, and curry.  Dry taste is noticable right away, with a bit of nuttiness, red wine/vinous flavor (works better in flavor), chocolate, and light soy.  Finish has a lot going on with a dry spicy hop flavor, fair bitterness giving way to hazelnut, toffee, and something tannic on the throat.  Full bodied, but a bit slick feeling for me.  Carbonation starts a bit high, but I swirled it away.  Pretty nice if not for that sour wine aroma.  Id rather have the Ambree though.

Bottle at the brewery  Deep brown body with a creamy, lightly brown head.  Balanced and quite compelx aroma of sweet malts, liquor, chocolate.  Lightly sweet, moderately bitter and somewhat sour flavour.  Quite complex flavour.  Interesting but spicy sweetness dominates maybe somewhat too much.

Bottle. [ Courtesy of drewbeerme ] Unclear medium amber red color with a average to large, frothy / creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, moderate yeasty, fruit, drie fruiy, light alcohol, vintage. (Very complex aroma). Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light acidic with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. Very nice beer ;o)) (151007)

Bottle: Foams over immediately. I pour into a pint glass and get a huge foamy head. Beer is deep brownish orange, slightly cloudy with lots of protein clumps floating around. It distracts from me drinking so i have to repour and filter it through a cheesecloth. Aroma is rich caramel and banana with some alcohol as well. Flavor is richl toasted caramel with banana and bubble gum phenols and perhaps some grape as well. Full body, sweet but fairly dry. Alcohol is well hidden in flavor. A sipper.

Great citrus smell, a lot of sediment and Im not sure if every bottle is as sedimentary as this one is.  

Very complex with hints of citrus and sweet fruit sweet for a tripel but smoothe and very drinkable.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a nice head. Aroma of dried fruit, wheat and spices. Great flavour of yeast, caramel, sweetness and wheat. Very nice endeed.

Not sure if I got a bad bottle, but it was like a snow globe after pouring with sediment flying throughout the entire experience. Good beer, want to try again, hopefully with better success. Love the flavor, hid the alcohol well.
750ml - Dark amber with almost no head.   Brown sugar, caramel,  fruits aroma and flavor.  Very nice beer.

Great dirty brown pour with a nice frothy head. Nose of ripe plums, raisins, nuts and bread. Taste is spicy sweetness, doughy raisin bread and candied sugar. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Solid finish.

11.2 oz bottle- poured ruby brown with heavy carbonation, slowly dissolving light tan head.  Aroma of fruit, spice, and earth.  Hits the mouth with a full body, consisting of sweetness, spices, and a hint of yeast.  Finish is subtle- alcohol lingers crossed with very slight hops.  Very enjoyable.

Luminous, volcanic red pour, the first being fully transparent and the second fully obscure, with a lovely head of very light beige that stays the course.  Aroma suggests apples, cinnamon, pine, and walnuts; tropical fruits fill in the back while heat settles in with a spiced rum and red pepper punch, becoming estery with banana notes and steamed vegetal tones upon the second and third pours.  Crisp, full and rich flavor of spruce, bitter chocolate, tangy table wine.  Thoroughly dark and fruity; intimations of raisin, plum, and cranberry, chocolate covered for the most part.  Lightly tart, but more vinous.    Yeast weighs in with wet, bready strength, tinted with caraway and pear.  Finishing flavor is of peat and candy sugar, very dark.  Palate is full and thick, though sprightly in that uniquely belgian sense.  Blossoms with warmth and dirty honey sweetness in an extended pulse, with a pine note that nearly overpowers.  Lacking surprises, certainly, but to no dissapointing effect.

The beer after its release from the 750ml bottle sets in the chalice a beclouded burgundy color an off white creamy head that towers over the luscious body, as it slowly decomposes; the lace forms a thick blanket upon the glass. Nose is rich with the aroma of black cherries, walnuts, sweet malt, hints of alcohol, and fresh toasted bread, what a treat to just smell this beer. Start is sweet with malt and cherries, touch of spices, and the top medium to full. Finish has a stern acidity, the hops delectable, the cherries and malt last to the dry ending, the alcohol warms the innards, and all I can say is Woo Hoo!

Hazy deep amber colour with an off white head. Malty, caramel and alcohol sweet aroma with fruity and light herbal notes. Caramel, fruit and alcohol sweet flavor with notes of yeast. Light dry and spicy finish.

Tap at the Fort Worth Flying Saucer Octoberfest.  Cloudy brown pour, quick fading head.  Nose is scipy and fruity.  Light to medium bodied with very active carbonation.  Spicy, peerery flavor with a slightly tart finish.  Very nice.
Kings and emperors... YES.  I thought this would be a tripel, due to the name of the beer, but I guess IMPERIAL Tripel = BSA.  At any rate, real good.

Pours a dark brown red color, slight tannish head, somewhat lasting. Dark grape aroma, very strong & wine-y. Very strong aroma. Strong dark fruit taste. Sour aftertaste. Malty grapey taste. Odd but not really my style.

This beer pours a deep amber/brown with a medium tan head.  The nose has sweet coke, plums sugars and when you take a sip, WOW!  All teh flavors meld together make this a lightly carbonated and semi sweet beer!  This beer has that classic belgianale/trappistale flavor!  and boy does it do a good job of mixing the flavors together.  Wondefully complex and good, It hides the 10% abv very well!  I think Ill have some more later!  Cheers!

Taster at the fall beer tasting at the Flying Saucer in Fort Worth.  Brown in color with a mediocre head, very cloudy.  Taste is malty sweet and has fruity flavor and has some alcohol taste.  Seems like a lot going on but it did not really work for me.

Print is a little smudged, but I think it says best before 2010. After wrestling to pour the geyser I am left with a beautiful ruby brown ale with a small but fluffy light tan head. Strong and semi-sweet aroma of apricot, flat cola, and an earthy/musty undertone. Kind of weird, but interesting and pleasant. Flavor is almost syrupy sweet, and kind of what I expected from the aroma, but not necessarily what I really wanted to get. The fruity notes are pleasant although a bit too sweet for my taste, but I also taste a good bit of that flat cola I got in the aroma. Its not all that bad, but doesnt balance out the sweet fruity flavors that are so prevalent. There is a really nice undertone of cinnamon though. The palate is medium/full, semi-sweet, with a long finish, and some slightly sharp carbonation. I am missing the huge yeasty chunks though (although I admit I found the huge gobs of yeast a bit much the last time I had a des Rocs)

75 cL bottle, thanks to sk8viking. Pours hazy amber with a lacing white head. Malty, dried fruity and somewhat slight cloying. Nice underplayed spiced flavour with a sweet maltbase. Ends with a great blend of all elements. Nice.
Ruby red pour with a big off white head. Very fruity aroma with some caramel. Very sweet but finishes nicely.

Bottle.
Hazy orange red coloured with a solid beige head.
Sweet aroma of caarmel, dired fruits and liquorice.
Sweet flavour of caramel, dired fruits, earth and yeast.
Yeasty finish.

What I said about the brune, but moreso. 
yeh, Im tired. Can say that it goes well with death.

(Bottle 75 cl) Courtesy of sk8viking. Very hazy amber golden with a small, off-white head. Spicy and sweet nose with some brown sugars. Quite full-bodied, rich with sweet caramels and some spices - as well as a slightly earthy/fusty edge. Plenty of brown sugars in there also. Basically no bitterness. 280907

Bottle. [Courtesy of Sk8viking, quality tasting @ Papsoe] Large creamy and thick beige head. Excellent film like lacework that just covered the inside of the glass. Muddy amber / brown color. Aroma was quit amazing and complex. A big fan of other brews from Abbaye Des Rocs, this one did not disappoint. With the well known Des Rocs yeasty like aroma. Also notes of bread, caramel, toffee, toasted malt, nutty, raisin, prune, fruit and spice. Very full bodied with a light alcoholic texture and an average carbonation. Heavy sweet flavor with light notes of acidic and bitter notes as well. Fruity and spicy lingering finish. Wow that was a fantastic beer. 28-09-2007

amber bronze color with creamy tan head.  aroma of dark cherries with a sweet roasted, and slightly spicy yeast note. medium light body. dark fruit, and cherry flavor with butter and honey toast and alcohol. amazingly easy drinking despite its intensity
Bottle. A dark amber beer with a tan head. The aroma is of dark fruits, caramel malt, brown sugar and alcohol, so is the taste, sweet. Full body with a sweet finish. A great beer !!!
Very fruity aroma with pear, pineapple and alcohol; some chocolate hints with a smooth, rounded and fairly clean palate; quite nice.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2010 750ml bottle.  Delicious cinnamon and clove scent.  Brown sugary sweet with just a hint of the 10% alcohol.  Murky amber-brown color with all sorts of particulates.  Nice foamy head.  Dark sweet fruity finish.  Great beer, great brewery! 9 5 10 4 18

Had this one again in a 11.2oz bottle and was not nearly as  impressed.  I found the alcohol to be really unpleasantly intense in the aroma.  Tasted like old school Abbey stuff.  Rugged, thick, yeasty and funky.  Tastes old.  Super candy sugar delight.  7 5 7 4 16

Its been a while since Ive had a Belgian, and one whiff reminded me of the complexity and tastiness of this style. Aroma was dark fruit, yeast and sugar. Pour was a dark brown with a huge 4 finger off white head that lasted the whole glass. Taste was strong...dark fruit, caramel and yeast mostly. There was some brown sugar and spiciness in the aftertaste. After a summer of simple wheat beers and pilseners this is a wake up call that my favorite times of year (fall and winter) are coming.

text: Picked this one out of the cellar for my 100th rating.  Pour was chocolate brown, heavy on particulates, and had a ruthless brown head...almost volcano-like!  Aroma was breathtaking...brown sugar and raisins rose to the top but hints of chocolate and dark fruits were also notable...simply wonderful.  Flavor was also excellent, though it did not fully reach the level of awe I had with the aroma.  Lightly carbonated, this ale had nice hints of yeast, burnt malts and brown sugar and a very nice lasting sweetness that was accented with the dark fruit flavors...grapes and raisins seemed to stick out.  I felt the alcohol was hidden very nicely in the initial taste, but warmed the palate a few seconds later.  Very nice palate as well...coats with a nice lasting sweetness.  This was one of the best beers I have consumed to date...glad I grabbed the 750ml!
